Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Strategy Problems for Robots and Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award aims at developing strategies that allow mobile robots and sensor networks to perform their tasks near-optimally, or at least competitively. The tasks considered in this proposal deal mainly with exploration, patroling, guarding and searching. Typical tasks are that a group of robots should explore an unknown structure consisting of rooms which are connected by passages, or that a mobile guard should patrol a set of corridors, so that he can look down each corridor once during his patrol round. A typical problem involving sensors is to place sensors with a limited sensing range in a region of interest in such a way that any intruder can move only a small distance without being discovered by a sensor. For each of these problems, a strategy needs to be developed, its worst-case performance needs to be analyzed, and it needs to be compared with the unknown optimal strategy, to show that the proposed strategy is nearly optimal. Some of the strategies developed in this project will be implemented and tested by a cooperating robotics lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to study optimal, or at least provably good, strategies for the distribution of  sensors or motion of robots in a region of interest. This region might be initially unknown, so this includes exploration problems. Some problems of this type that were studied under this project are

  • Path Planning for tethered robots: A robot that is connected to a tether, e.g., a power cable, needs to perform substantially different path planning in the presence of obstacles than a classical untethered robot. A faster algorithm for shortest path planning of a tethered robot was developed.
  • Exploration of an unknown graph by multiple robots: For a single robot, the problem of exploring an unknown graph with opaque edges is well-understood, and DFS is essentially optimal. The same problem for multiple robots is still open. A strategy was found that is good for exploring trees, with optimum competitive ratio for two robots. It is also near optimal for graphs with a superlinear edge number, but unfortunately it fails for graphs with linear edge number that are not trees.
  • Reconstructing an event set from local information in a sensor network: Suppose there are sensor that sense some event, e.g., "it rains". Then the answer that is desired is the region in which it rains, but the answer given by the network is a set of points at which rain was detected, which is subject to sensing errors, and therefore does not immediately translate to a region. A local majority vote strategy was analyzed and shown to significantly improve the identification of the correct region.  

In addition to these and similar problems, the PI organized twice the "Fall Workshop on Computational Geometry" (in 2011 and 2013), supported and advised two doctoral students, and, in a no-cost-extension period, started the "Workshop on Geometric Problems in Sensor Networks and Robotics".

As intellectual merit, the project published its results in recognized journals of the field. The most interesting of these intellectual contributions concerns probably the multirobot exploration of graphs.

As broader impact, the workshops organized by the PI are a valuable contribution to the computational geometry community, as well as bringing computational geometry to the students at CCNY, which is a hispanic-serving institution in Harlem, Manhattan, NY. The most lasting impact is probably by starting the "Workshop on Geometric Problems in Sensor Networks and Robotics", which is closely aligned with the topic of the project, and which was held with good success twice (2015, 2016), with several collagues expressing interest to host it in 2017.
